fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Abstract Algebra

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: References to theorems will be made by ⟨chapter⟩.⟨section⟩.⟨theorem number⟩, but references to definitions will be made by ⟨chapter⟩.⟨section⟩.

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 14.6.32
Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 14.6.33

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field of characteristic \mathop {\textrm {char}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F})\neq 2, let \sigma \in S_{n} be a permutation. Then \sigma \in A_{n} if and only if it fixes the squareroot of the Discriminant D.
In other words, \mathbb {F}(s_{1},…,s_{n},\sqrt {D}) is a quadratic extension over \mathbb {F}(s_{1},…,s_{n}), and its Galois group is A_{n}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Character
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 14.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Character of a group G with values in a field \mathbb {F} is a group morphism \chi \colon G\to \mathbb {F}^{\times }. In particular, this means \chi (gh)=\chi (g)\chi (h) for all g,h\in G.

We will write \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits _{\mathbf {Grp}}(G,\mathbb {F}^{\times }) (or \mathop {\textrm {Hom}}\nolimits (G,\mathbb {F}^{\times }) if there's no risk of ambiguity) for the set of all characters of G with values in \mathbb {F}.

fr:title.text: Constructibility of regular polygon by straightedge and compass

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Constructibility of regular polygon by straightedge and compass
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 14.5.29

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for simple radical extensions
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 14.7.36

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N}. Let \mathbb {F} be a field containing the n^{\text {th}} roots of unity. If \mathop {\textrm {char}}\nolimits (\mathbb {F})\nmid n, then for any a\in \mathbb {F} the extension \mathbb {F}(\sqrt [n]{a}) ic cyclic over \mathbb {F} of degree dividing n.
Here \sqrt [n]{a} is any solution to x^{n}-a\in \mathbb {F}[x].

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We say \mathbb {F}(\sqrt [n]{a}) is a Simple Radical Extension of \mathbb {F}.

fr:title.text: Distinct embeddings of fields are linearly independent

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Distinct embeddings of fields are linearly independent
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Corollary 14.2.8

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F}, \Bbbk be fields. If \sigma _{1},…,\sigma _{n}\colon \mathbb {F}\to \Bbbk are distinct field embeddings (i.e., nonzero field morphisms), then they are linearly independent.

We see \sigma \colon \mathbb {F}\to \Bbbk is a field morphism iff \sigma \colon \mathbb {F}^{\times }\to \Bbbk ^{\times } is a group morphism. Equivalently, \sigma is a character of \mathbb {F}^{\times } with values in \Bbbk . Since field morphisms preserve zero, we see the Linear Independence of Characters implies the result.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Galois extension and Galois group
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 14.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If f(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] is separable and \Bbbk is the splitting field of f(x), then \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}) is called the Galois Group of f(x).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We follow Dummit and Foote in defining the Galois group of an extension so that \mathop {\textrm {Gal}}\nolimits (\Bbbk / \mathbb {F}) has the maximal number of automorphisms. Some authors are more generous and just treat the Galois group as a synonym for the Automorphism group for field extensions, any arbitrary field extension.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Linear Independence of Characters
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 14.2.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \chi _{1}, …, \chi _{n} are distinct characters of G with values in \mathbb {F}, then they are linearly independent over \mathbb {F}.
(Proof by contradiction) Assume \chi _{1}, …, \chi _{n} are linearly dependent. By removing some \chi _{i}, we can assume any proper subset of \{\chi _{1},…,\chi _{n}\} is independent.

fr:title.text: Group of n^{{th}} roots of unity

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Group of n^{\text {th}} roots of unity
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML uniroots:def 3
Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 13.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The group of all n^{\text {th}} roots of unity (equipped with multiplication) is denoted \mu _{n}.
Exercise: Prove \mu _{n}\cong \mathbb {Z} / n\mathbb {Z} as groups (with addition on the right-hand side, but multiplication on the left-hand side).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of Algebraic Closures
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 13.4.30

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field. Then there exists an algebraically closed field \mathbb {L} containing \mathbb {F}.

Let \mathbb {L} be a field such that
\mathbb {F}\subseteq \mathbb {L}, and
|\mathbb {L}| > \max (|\mathbb {F}|,\aleph _{0})=:\mathcal {N} (to ensure \mathbb {L} is a set, not a proper class). Then we can turn this into a lattice with ordering given by inclusion. Then by Zorn's lemma, there exists a maximal element L_{0} which we will prove is the algebraic closure of \mathbb {F}.

Proof by contradiction: Assume for contradiction L_{0} is not an algebraic closure of \mathbb {F}. Then there exists a nonconstant polynomial f(x)\in L_{0}[x] which has no root in L_{0}. Then there exists an algebraic extension W of L_{0} which has a root of f(x) (say, the splitting field of f(x) over L_{0}). Since W is an algebraic extension of L_{0}, we have |L_{0}|\leq |W|\leq \mathcal {N}, hence |S\setminus L_{0}|=|S|>|W\setminus L_{0}|. So there exists an injection i\colon W\to S such that i(x)=x for all x\in L_{0}. If we induce by i an algebraic structure from W onto i(W) we obtain a new maximal element of the lattice which is greater than L_{0}, giving us our contradiction. Hence L_{0} must be an algebraic closure of \mathbb {F}.

(1) Jelonek proved this in 1993, which cleaned up a more sloppy version of the same proof by Artin. Lang's Algebra (Theorem V.2.6 and its Corollary) follows Artin's proof, as well, but carefully patches it. In fact, it seems Lang's approach has become more or less standard.
(2) Jelonek's proof also establishes that the cardinality of the algebraic closure of \mathbb {F} is \max (|\mathbb {F}|,\aleph _{0}). In particular, the algebraic closure is always infinite.

fr:title.text: Field isomorphisms extends to splitting fields

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field isomorphisms extends to splitting fields
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML field_8:57
Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 13.4.27

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f(x)=a_{n}x^{n}+…+a_{1}x+a_{0}\in \mathbb {F}[x] be a polynomial, let \varphi \colon \mathbb {F}\to \mathbb {F}' be a field isomorphism, and g(x)\in \mathbb {F}'[x] be a polynomial obtained by applying \varphi to the coefficients of f(x). If \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is a splitting field of f(x), and \Bbbk '/\mathbb {F}' is a splitting field of g(x), then \varphi extends to an isomorphism \varphi '\colon \Bbbk \to \Bbbk '.
Proof by induction on \deg (f).

Base case: \deg (f)=1, then f(x)=x-\alpha for some \alpha \in \mathbb {F} and g(x)=x-\varphi (\alpha ). Then \mathbb {F} is the splitting field of f(x) and \mathbb {F}' the splitting field of g(x), and \varphi is an isomorphism of the two trivially extending itself.
Inductive case: Suppose the result holds for polynomials of degree strictly less than n (where n=\deg (f)).
Let \alpha _{1}\in \Bbbk be a root of f(x) and f_{1}(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] is an irreducible factor of f(x) such that f_{1}(\alpha )=0.

Set F_{1}=\mathbb {F}(\alpha _{1}). Let g_{1}(x) be the polynomial obtained from f_{1}(x) by applying \varphi to the coefficients. Then g_{1}(x) is irreducible over \mathbb {F}' since f_{1}(x) is irreducible over \mathbb {F}. Let \beta _{1}\in \Bbbk ' be a root of g_{1}(x) and set F'_{1}=\mathbb {F}'(\beta ). Isomorphisms of fields extends to isomorphisms of simple field extensions implies the isomorphism \varphi \colon \mathbb {F}\to \mathbb {F}' extends to an isomorphism \varphi _{1}\colon F_{1}\to F'_{1}. Writing f(x)=(x-\alpha )f_{0}(x) and g(x)=(x-\beta )g_{0}(x), we have g_{0}\in F'_{1}[x] is obtained by applying \varphi _{1} to the coefficients of f_{0}(x)\in F_{1}[x].
By the inductive hypothesis, the field \Bbbk is a splitting field for f_{0}(x) over \mathbb {F}_{1}.
Similarly, \Bbbk ' is a splitting field for g_{0}(x) over F'_{1}.

Since \deg (f_{0})=\deg (g_{0})=n-1<n, the inductive hypothesis ensures the existence of an isomorphism \varphi '\colon \Bbbk \to \Bbbk ' extending \varphi _{1}\colon F_{1}\to F'_{1}, which itself extends \varphi \colon \mathbb {F}\to \mathbb {F}'. The result follows immediately.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Algebraic Element
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 13.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} be a Field extension. An element \alpha \in \Bbbk is called Algebraic Over \mathbb {F} if there is some nonzero p(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] such that p(\alpha )=0. Otherwise we say \alpha is Transcendental over \mathbb {F}.

When all elements of \Bbbk are algebraic elements over \mathbb {F}, we say the field extension \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is an Algebraic Extension. Otherwise we say \Bbbk / \mathbb {F} is a Transcendental Extension.

fr:title.text: Generic form a finite field extension

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Generic form a finite field extension
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 13.1.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathbb {F} be a field, let p(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x] be a nonconstant irreducible polynomial of degree \deg (p)=n, and let \Bbbk =\mathbb {F}[x]/(p(x)). Let \alpha \in \Bbbk be the image of x under the quotient map \pi \colon \mathbb {F}[x]\twoheadrightarrow \Bbbk , then \{1,\alpha ,…,\alpha ^{n-1}\} is a basis for \Bbbk as a vector space over \mathbb {F}. In particular, [\Bbbk : \mathbb {F}]=n.
We see \{1,\alpha ,…,\alpha ^{n-1}\} spans \Bbbk over \mathbb {F} as a vector space since it is the image of \{1,x,…,x^{n-1},…\} and that spans \mathbb {F}[x] over \mathbb {F}.

Let \beta \in \Bbbk be the image of some b(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x]. By the division algorithm, b(x)=q(x)p(x)+r(x) where 0\leq \deg (r)<n=\deg (p). Observe if \alpha is the image of x under the quotient map, then b(\alpha )=q(\alpha )\cdot 0+r(\alpha )=r(\alpha ). Since \deg (r)<n, we have b(\alpha )=c_{0}+c_{1}\alpha +…+c_{n-1}\alpha ^{n-1}, which implies b(\alpha )=\beta \in \mathop {\textrm {span}}\nolimits (1,\alpha ,…,\alpha ^{n-1}). Since \beta \in \Bbbk was arbitrary, and we showed it was a linear combination of the proposed basis, we have obtained the result.

fr:title.text: Simple field extensions are isomorphic to quotient fields with respect to principal ideals generated by irreducible polynomials

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Simple field extensions are isomorphic to quotient fields with respect to principal ideals generated by irreducible polynomials
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 13.1.6

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The choice of \alpha in this theorem is irrelevant.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We see \mathbb {F}[x]/(p(x)) is a field since p(x) is irreducible. Since e_{\alpha } is nonzero, it must be injective. Then the image of e_{\alpha } must be a subfield of \Bbbk and also contained in \mathbb {F}(\alpha ), in particular the image of e_{\alpha } must contain \alpha . Since F(\alpha ) is the minimal such field, e_{\alpha } must be surjective.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: p-Primary Component
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 12.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain, let M be a finitely-generated R-module. Let p be a prime element of R. Then a p-Primary Component of M is a submodule M(p) of M such that:
M=\bigoplus _{p}M(p), and
If M=M(p), then M=\bigoplus _{i}^{m}R/p^{\alpha _{i}}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We have two conditions: either M(p)=\{x\in M\mid p^{r}x=0,r\geq 0\}, or M[p^{r}]=\{x\in M\mid p^{r}x=0\} where p^{r}\mathrel {\bigm |}\mathop {\textrm {Ann}}\nolimits _{R}(M).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Submodule criteria
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 10.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let R be a Ring, let M be an R-module, and let N\subseteq M be a subset of M. Then N is a submodule of M if and only if
N\neq \emptyset and
for all r\in R and x,y\in N, we have x+ry\in N.

fr:title.text: Submodules of a rank n free module over a PID are free and have rank less than or equal to n

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Submodules of a rank n free module over a PID are free and have rank less than or equal to n
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 12.1.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain, let M be an R-module. If M\leq R^{n} is free, then M is free and the rank of M is bounded as \mathop {\textrm {rank}}\nolimits (M)\leq n.
By induction on n. The base case is trivial.

The inductive case, we write R^{n}=R^{n-1}\oplus R and take F_{0}=R^{n-1}. Then M\cap F_{0}\subseteq M. Let us call this M_{0}=M\cap F_{0}. By induction M_{0} is free, finitely-generated of rank at most n-1.
If M=M_{0}, then we're done.

If M\neq M_{0}, then we have to consider some element of R which generates the rest of M. We look at I=\{\alpha \mid \alpha e_{n}+f_{0}\in M,f_{0}\in F_{0}\}, and the claim is that I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R is a nonzero ideal. This is because I=(0) iff M\subseteq F_{0}. So I\neq (0) is generated by a single nonzero element (since R is a principal ideal domain), say I=(\gamma ). Then M=M_{0}\oplus R\omega where \omega =e_{n}\gamma +f\in M.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Abstract Chinese Remainder Theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 7.6.17
Hungerford Algebra Theorem III.2.25

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let R be a Ring. Let I and J be comaximal two-sided ideals of R. Then
the map R/(I\cap J)\to (R/I)\times (R/J) defined by sending x\mapsto (x+I,x+J) is a Ring Isomorphism; and
furthermore if we write I\cdot J=\langle \{ab\in R\mid a\in I,b\in J\}\rangle for the two-sided ideal generated by products of elements of I and J, then I\cdot J=I\cap J.

(1) Let \varphi \colon R\to (R/I)\times (R/J) be the mapping such that \varphi (x)=(x+I,x+J) for any x\in R. Its kernel is I\cap J. Then by the first isomorphism theorem \varphi '\colon R/(I\cap J)\to (R/I)\times (R/J) is injective because it has a trivial kernel. We need to show it is surjective.

(2) Since I and J are comaximal, there exists a\in I and b\in J such that a+b=1. We want to show I\cap J\subseteq I\cdot J. Let x\in I\cap J. Then x=x\cdot 1=xa+xb, so xa\in JI and xb\in IJ, hence x\in I\cdot J.
We see I\cap J\supseteq I\cdot J obviously.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Comaximal ideals
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a unital Commutative Ring. Let A\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R and B\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be ideals of R. We say A and B are Comaximal if their sum is the entire ring A+B=R.
We see that this is a symmetric predicate in A and B since A+B=B+A.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eisenstein criteria of reducibility
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 9.4.13

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be an Integral domain, let x be a formal variable. Let f(x)\in R[x] be a (nonconstant) monic polynomial f(x)=x^{n}+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+…+a_{1}x+a_{0}. Let P\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be a prime ideal of R. Suppose for all j=1,…,n we have p_{j}\in R and a_{0}\notin P^{2}. Then f(x) is irreducible.

Since P is a prime ideal, R/P is an integral domain (by Ideal is prime iff quotient ring is integral domain). Then both \overline {a(x)} and \overline {b(x)} have 0 constant terms, i.e., the constant terms of both a(x) and b(x) belong to P.
But then the constant term a_{0} of f(x) may be written as the product of these two, which contradicts the hypothesis that a_{0}\notin P^{2}.
Exercise: Is p(x)=x^{5}-4x^{4}+2 irreducible in \mathbb {Q}[x] or not?

fr:title.text: Factorization of formal polynomials with coefficients in UFDs

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Factorization of formal polynomials with coefficients in UFDs
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 9.3.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Unique Factorization Domain, let \mathbb {F}=\mathop {\textrm {Frac}}\nolimits (R) be its field of fractions, let x be a formal variable. Let p(x)\in R[x].

If p(x) is reducible in \mathbb {F}[x], then p(x) is reducible in R[x]. More precisely: if p(x)=A(x)B(x) for some nonconstant polynomials A(x),B(x)\in \mathbb {F}[x], then there are nonzero elements r,s\in \mathbb {F} such that rA(x)=a(x) and sB(x)=b(x) both lie in R[x] and p(x)=a(x)b(x) is a factorization in R[x].

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is called "Gauss's Lemma", but as far as I can tell, like most things named after Gauss, it's completely unmerited.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Corollary 8.3.15

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The integers are a unique factorization domain.

fr:title.text: In a UFD, elements are irreducible iff prime

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: In a UFD, elements are irreducible iff prime
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 8.3.12

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Unique Factorization Domain, let p\in R be an element of R. Then p is prime if and only if p is irreducible.
(\Longrightarrow ) Well, since a UFD is an integral domain, this follows immediately from Nonzero prime elements of an integral domain are irreducible.
(\Longleftarrow ) Assume p is irreducible. We want to prove p is prime.

Let a,b\in R be arbitrary. Assume p\mathrel {\bigm |} ab. Then there exists some c\in R such that ab=pc. We can write the unique factorization of a as a=u\prod ^{N}_{i=1}p_{i}^{n_{i}} and the unique factorization of b as b=v\prod ^{M}_{j=1}q_{j}^{m_{j}} and the unique factorization of c as c=w\prod ^{L}_{k=1}r_{k}^{\ell _{k}}. Then p must associate with one of the irreducibles appearing in the factorization of a or {b}. We have ab=pc be uv\prod ^{N}_{i=1}p_{i}^{n_{i}}\prod ^{M}_{j=1}q_{j}^{m_{j}}=wp\prod ^{L}_{k=1}r_{k}^{\ell _{k}}, and by uniqueness of the factorizations N+M-1=L, and either p_{i}=pu'\quad \hbox {for some }i\hbox { and }u'\in R^{\times } (which means p\mathrel {\bigm |} a), or q_{j}=pu'\quad \hbox {for some }j\hbox { and }u'\in R^{\times } (which means p\mathrel {\bigm |} b). Hence p\mathrel {\bigm |} ab implies p\mathrel {\bigm |} a or p\mathrel {\bigm |} b, which implies p is a prime element of R.

fr:title.text: Principal ideal domains are unique factorization domains

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Principal ideal domains are unique factorization domains
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 8.3.14

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Principal Ideal Domain, let a\in R be a nonzero non-invertible element of R. Then there exists irreducible elements p_{1},…,p_{n}\in R such that a=p_{1}(…)p_{n}. Further, if q_{1},…,q_{m}\in R are irreducible and such that a=q_{1}(…)q_{m} then m=n and for each i=1,…,n we have q_{i}=u_{i}p_{i} where u\in R^{\times } is a unit.
In other words, R is a Unique Factorization Domain.
There are two claims: (1) there is a factorization, and (2) the factorization is unique.
Claim 1: Existence of a factorization. Assume for contradiction a\in R does not have a factorization. Then ua\in R does not have a factorization for any unit u\in R^{\times }.
We setup a set S:=\{(r)\mathrel {\triangleleft } R\mid r\hbox { does not have a factorization into irreducibles}\}. Assume for contradiction that S\neq \emptyset .

Let (a) be a maximal element of S by Zorn's lemma. We have a is not irreducible, so by definition we can write it as a=xy where x,y\notin R^{\times } are not units, so (a)\subset (x) and (a)\subset (y) are proper subsets.

But since (a) is a maximal element of a chain, (x)
otin S and (y)
otin S, so x and y have a factorization. This gives us a contradiction, which means our assumption S
eq \emptyset is wrong. We conclude S=\emptyset . Hence we've proven the factorization of elements exists.

Claim 2: Uniqueness of factorization. This may be proven in many, many ways. Assume for contradiction this is not true, so we may factorize \prod ^{n}_{i}p_{i}=\prod ^{m}_{j}q_{j}, where n is minimal (i.e., the factorization \prod ^{n}_{i}p_{i} is the smallest possible factorization with fewest possible factors).

We have n\geq 1, p=p_{1} divides p\mathrel {\bigm |}\prod q_{j}. Then there exists a j_{0} such that p\mathrel {\bigm |} q_{j_{0}} since p_{i} and q_{j} are all prime and irreducible. Then p=uq_{j_{0}} for some unit u\in R^{\times } (since p and q_{j_{0}} are irreducible). Then p_{1}\prod ^{n}_{i=2}p_{i}=(uq_{j_{0}})u^{-1}\prod ^{m}_{j\neq j_{0}}q_{j} which implies \prod ^{n}_{i=2}p_{i}=u^{-1}\prod ^{m}_{j\neq j_{0}}q_{j}. This contradicts the assumption that \prod ^{n}_{i=1}p_{i} is the minimal factorization.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Universal property of free modules
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 10.3.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a set, let R be a Ring. There exists an R-module F(A) called the Free Module of A such that: for any R-module M and function of sets \varphi \colon A\to M, there exists a unique R-linear map \Phi \colon F(A)\to M such that for all a\in A we have \Phi (a)=\varphi (a) for all a\in A.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Euclidean Domain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 8.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An Integral domain R is said to be a Euclidean Domain if there is a norm N\colon R\to \mathbb {N}_{0} such that for any two elements a,b\in R with b\neq 0, there exists elements [the quotient] q\in R and [the remainder] r\in R such that a=qb+r and r=0\quad \hbox {or}\quad N(r)<N(b).

fr:title.text: Euclidean Domains are Principal Ideal Domains

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Euclidean Domains are Principal Ideal Domains
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 8.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every ideal in a Euclidean Domain is principal: if R is any Euclidean domain and I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R with 0\neq I, then I=(d) where d is any nonzero element of I of minimum norm.

fr:title.text: Field morphisms are injective nonzero ring morphisms

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field morphisms are injective nonzero ring morphisms
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Corollary 7.4.10

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \mathbb {F} is a Field, then any nonzero Ring morphism from \mathbb {F} into another ring must be an Injective function.
The Kernel of a ring morphism is an ideal. The kernel of a nonzero morphism is a proper ideal, hence must be 0 by Field morphisms are injective nonzero ring morphisms.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Fields only have trivial ideals
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.4.9(2)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring. Then R is a Field if and only if its only ideals are 0 and R.
We see R is a field iff every nonzero element is a unit (by definition of a field).
(\Longrightarrow ) If R is a field, then every nonzero ideal contains a unit, which means that R is the only nonzero ideal.

(\Longleftarrow ) Suppose the only ideals of R is the trivial ideal and R itself. Let u be any nonzero element of R. Then (u)=R so 1\in (u). Hence there must be some v\in R such that 1=vu (i.e., u is a unit). Therefore every nonzero element of R is a unit, hence R must be a field.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideal
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.3
Artin Algebra Section 11.3
Hungerford Algebra Section III.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring. A (Two-Sided) Ideal of R is a nonempty subset I\subseteq R such that I is a left ideal and a right ideal of R.
Furthermore, when I\neq R we say I is a Proper (two-sided) ideal of R.

Some authors use the notation I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq }R to indicate I is an ideal of R, as well as I\mathrel {\triangleleft }R for proper ideals, analogous to the notation used for Normal subgroups.
(1) For commutative rings, any left ideal is also a right ideal, and so we just speak of "ideals".
(2) "Ideal" originally described "ideal elements" adjoined to a ring, which are not "real".
(3) A two-sided ideal forms a Subring of R, same for one-sided ideals of R.

(4) Traditionally, the historic notation used to indicate we're working with ideals was to use fraktur letters (\mathfrak {a}, \mathfrak {b}, \mathfrak {c}, and so on). This was a horrible decision. Modern conventions use I, J, and variants using apostrophes or indices.

fr:title.text: Ideal is maximal iff quotient ring is field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideal is maximal iff quotient ring is field
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.4.12

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring, let M\mathrel {\triangleleft } R be an ideal. Then M is Maximal ideal if and only if the Quotient Ring R/M is a Field.

fr:title.text: Ideal is prime iff quotient ring is integral domain

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideal is prime iff quotient ring is integral domain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.4.13

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring, let P\mathrel {\triangleleft } R be an ideal. Then P is Prime Ideal if and only if the Quotient Ring R/P is a Integral domain.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideal generated by a set
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a unital Ring with 1\neq 0. Let A\subseteq R be any subset of R. Then the Ideal Generated by A is the ideal \langle A\rangle of R equal to \langle A\rangle = \bigcap _{A\subseteq I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R}I. This is the smallest ideal of R containing A.
When A=\{a_{1},…,a_{n}\} is a finite set, then we just write \langle a_{1},…,a_{n}\rangle or (a_{1},…,a_{n}) for the ideal generated by A.
Exercise: What is \langle \emptyset \rangle the ideal generated by the empty set?
Exercise: If we allow R to be a nonunital ring, then is the ideal generated by a set still well-defined?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Left ideal of a ring
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML ideal_1:def 1
Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.3
Artin Algebra Section 11.3
Hungerford Algebra Section III.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let R be a Ring. A Left Ideal of R is a nonempty subset I\subseteq R such that
for any r\in R and x\in I we have rx\in I; and
for any x,y\in I we have x+y\in I.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We could speak of ideals in more general settings, e.g., rings without negation.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Commutative Ring. Let x\notin R be a formal variable (just a symbol, not a number). We define the Ring of Polynomials with coefficients R and in unknown x to be the ring R[x] consisting of formal polynomials which are finite sums p(x)=\sum ^{n}_{k=0}a_{k}x^{k} where a_{n}\neq 0, addition is done with the coefficients of each power, and multiplication is done using the Cauchy convolution product \left (\sum ^{m}_{j=0}a_{j}x^{j}\right )\left (\sum ^{n}_{k=0}b_{k}x^{k}\right )=\sum ^{m+n}_{k=0}\left (\sum ^{k}_{j=0}a_{j}b_{k-j}\right )x^{k}. Then this forms a commutative ring.
(2) We could generalize this to noncommutative R, but there are subtle issues which cause problems best left to be revisited in a graduate level algebra course.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Principal Ideal Domain
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An Integral domain R is called a Principal Ideal Domain if every ideal is principal (i.e., generated by a single element).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quotient Ring
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 7.3.6
Artin Algebra Section 11.3
Hungerford Algebra Theorem III.2.7
MML ring_1:def 6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a Ring and I\mathrel {\trianglelefteq } R be an Ideal of R. Then the additive quotient group R/I is a ring under the following binary operators (r+I)+(s+I)=(r+s)+I and (r+I)(s+I)=(rs)+I for all r,s\in R.

Furthermore,
If R is commutative, then R/I is commutative.
If R is unital, then R/I is unital.

To prove well-definedness, we should prove R/I equipped with these operators form a ring (since existence and uniqueness follow from the quotient group). Specifically, that multiplication exists and satisfies the various axioms.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right ideal of a ring
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML ideal_1:def 2
Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.3
Artin Algebra Section 11.3
Hungerford Algebra Section III.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let R be a Ring. A Right Ideal of R is a nonempty subset I\subseteq R such that
for any r\in R and x\in I we have xr\in I; and
for any x,y\in I we have x+y\in I.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ring morphism
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 7.3
Artin Algebra Section 11.3
Hungerford Algebra Section III.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R and S be Rings. We define a Ring Morphism (or just a Morphism if unambiguous) to be a function \varphi \colon R\to S such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: Additive: for any x,y\in R we have \varphi (x+y)=\varphi (x)+\varphi (y)
Preserves zero: \varphi (0_{R})=0_{S}
Multiplicative: for any x,y\in R we have \varphi (xy)=\varphi (x)\varphi (y)
Preserves one (when between unital rings): \varphi (1_{R})=1_{S} when there is a 1_{R}\in R and 1_{S}\in S

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Exercise: Do we really need \varphi (0)=0 or is this a consequence of additivity?
Exercise: Do we really need \varphi (1_{R})=1_{S} or is this a consequence of the multiplicative property?

fr:title.text: Action of a group on another group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Action of a group on another group
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Sections 1.7 and 2.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G and K be Groups. An (Left) Action of G on K is an uncurried form of the group morphism \rho \colon G\to \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (K); i.e., it's a morphism \alpha \colon G\times K\to K such that \alpha (g,k)=\rho (g)(k).
Usually we write g\cdot k instead of \alpha (g,k) for the left action of G on K, where g\in G and k\in K.
(1) This may be viewed as a special case of a Left group action.
(2) The \rho \colon G\to \mathop {\textrm {Aut}}\nolimits (K) group morphism is called a Representation of G on the group K.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cayley's theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML cayley:14
Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Corollary 4.2.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Then there is some symmetric group \mathop {\textrm {Sym}}\nolimits (G) and some subgroup H\leq \mathop {\textrm {Sym}}\nolimits {G} such that G\cong H.
Moreover, if the order of G is n, then G is isomorphic to a subgroup of S_{n}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Class equation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Theorem 4.3.7
MML weddwitt:14

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a finite Group. Then |G| = |Z(G)| + \sum _{x}[G : C_{G}(x)] where the sum is taken over representatives from the representatives from distinct conjugacy classes disjoint from the center of G.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Nothing in the proof required G being specifically finite, but we end up with a decomposition of infinite cardinal numbers in the infinite G case...which is not as useful...

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Conjugation action
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 2.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. The Conjugation Action is an action of G on itself given by g\cdot x:=g^{-1}xg conjugation.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Orbit-Stabilizer theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 4.1.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group and X be a nonempty set. Suppose G acts on X. Then for each x\in X, the cardinality of the Orbit G\cdot x is equal to the index of the Stabilizer of x, [G : G_{x}]=|G\cdot x|.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Permutation representation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 4.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let G be a Group. A Permutation Representation of G on X is a group morphism \rho \colon G\to \mathop {\textrm {Sym}}\nolimits (X) from G to the symmetric group of X.
When g\in G and x\in X, we write g\cdot x instead of \rho (g)(x). If there's ambiguity, we'll write \rho _{g}(x) to stress which representation we're using.

More generally, a Permutation Representation of G (without any mention of the representation space X) consists of a set X equipped with a group morphism \rho \colon G\to \mathop {\textrm {Sym}}\nolimits (X).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is a "curried" form of a Left group action.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Centralizer of a subset
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 2.2
MML group_22:def 4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group, let A be a subset of G. Then the Centralizer of A is the subgroup C_{G}(A)=\{g\in G\mid \forall a\in A\ldotp gag^{-1}=a\} consisting of all elements of G which commutes with every element of A.

fr:title.text: Criteria for a subset to be a subgroup

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Criteria for a subset to be a subgroup
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 2.1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group, let H\neq \emptyset be a nonempty subset of G. If for any x,y\in H we have xy^{-1}\in H, then H forms a Subgroup.
Furthermore, if H is finite, then it suffices to check that H is closed under multiplication (i.e., for any x,y\in H we have xy\in H).
If x=y, then xx^{-1}=e\in H contains the identity element.
For any x\in H, we have ex^{-1}=x^{-1}\in H, so H is closed under inverting elements.
For any x,y\in H, we have y^{-1}\in H, so x(y^{-1})^{-1}=xy\in H, which means H is closed under its binary operator.
Hence altogether H forms a subgroup of G.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subgroup
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML group_2:def 5
Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 2.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. A Subgroup of G is a group H such that its underlying set of elements is a subset of the set of elements of G, and the binary operator of H is the same as the binary operator of G restricted to H.
When H is a subgroup of G, we write H\leq G.
When H\neq G, we say H is a Proper Subgroup of G and write H\mathrel {<} G.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Torsion subgroup
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Exercise 2.1.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be an Abelian group. We define the Torsion Subgroup of G to be the Subgroup H=\{g\in G\mid \mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (g)<\infty \}.

fr:title.text: Traditional way of teaching abstract algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Traditional way of teaching abstract algebra

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The traditional way we teach undergraduates is by introducing several types of gadgets in abstract algebra in the following order:

fr:ol.fr:li: Initially, there's some discussion of set theory sufficient for developing algebra. This is "time honored tradition" starting with van der Waerden's book.

When the structure-preserving transformations leave something invariant (e.g., Invariant subspaces in linear algebra), composing such transformations also leaves the thing invariant. This is the guiding intuition of what a "symmetry" is, and the "collection of symmetries" is precisely what a "group" is (originally, they were a "group of symmetries" or a symmetry group).

fr:li.fr:p: (a) But we also saw how, e.g., square matrices have a neat algebraic structure with matrix addition and matrix multiplication. They act like a "number system". This is precisely what is studied with number ring (or just a Ring). A sufficiently nice ring is a Field.
(b) We can generalize linear algebra to describe "vector spaces over arbitrary rings", and these are modules.

fr:ol.fr:li: Galois theory is offered as the pinnacle of abstract algebra, connecting group theory to field theory. Honestly, I never understood the excitement behind Galois theory, since the beautiful parts of it are just the representation theory of groups (describing how "the same symmetries appearing in different situations").

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This is just the first 7 chapters of van der Waerden's Modern Algebra, Vol. I. Most textbooks have followed this manner of presentation: Dummit and Foote's Abstract Algebra covers this material in the first 14 chapters; Hungerford's Algebra does this in the first 6 chapters.

This is loosely following the material covered in the Math 5 series at California Institute of Technology (based on Dummit and Foote's Abstract Algebra) or the Math 150 series at University of California, Davis (based on Artin's Algebra).
We have already seen a number of different "species" of Mathematical Gadgets, like:

It turns out, all the information which was really interesting was encoded in the "structure-preserving transformations" between them. (That was the bulk of our time spent studying Elementary linear algebra and Intermediate linear algebra, after all!)
We can form an abstraction describing this situation where we have a [gadget] and [transformations] between them: this is category theory.

fr:title.text: Traditional way of teaching abstract algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Traditional way of teaching abstract algebra

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The traditional way we teach undergraduates is by introducing several types of gadgets in abstract algebra in the following order:

fr:ol.fr:li: Initially, there's some discussion of set theory sufficient for developing algebra. This is "time honored tradition" starting with van der Waerden's book.

When the structure-preserving transformations leave something invariant (e.g., Invariant subspaces in linear algebra), composing such transformations also leaves the thing invariant. This is the guiding intuition of what a "symmetry" is, and the "collection of symmetries" is precisely what a "group" is (originally, they were a "group of symmetries" or a symmetry group).

fr:li.fr:p: (a) But we also saw how, e.g., square matrices have a neat algebraic structure with matrix addition and matrix multiplication. They act like a "number system". This is precisely what is studied with number ring (or just a Ring). A sufficiently nice ring is a Field.
(b) We can generalize linear algebra to describe "vector spaces over arbitrary rings", and these are modules.

fr:ol.fr:li: Galois theory is offered as the pinnacle of abstract algebra, connecting group theory to field theory. Honestly, I never understood the excitement behind Galois theory, since the beautiful parts of it are just the representation theory of groups (describing how "the same symmetries appearing in different situations").

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This is just the first 7 chapters of van der Waerden's Modern Algebra, Vol. I. Most textbooks have followed this manner of presentation: Dummit and Foote's Abstract Algebra covers this material in the first 14 chapters; Hungerford's Algebra does this in the first 6 chapters.

fr:title.text: Modern ways to teach abstract algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modern ways to teach abstract algebra

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The more modern approaches to teaching abstract algebra incorporates some degree of category theory into the mix.

Aluffi's Algebra: Chapter 0 is perhaps the most bold attempt to reorganize abstract algebra around category theory entirely. Instead of ending at Galois theory, Aluffi concludes with homological algebra.
Some ideas from the traditional approach (like "groups with operators") turn out to be confused and muddled (which should be replaced with groups acting on other groups).

If I had to teach abstract algebra to undergraduates, I am torn between the traditional approaches (starting from van der Waerden's Moderne Algebra onwards) which I just outlined, and more modern adaptations which wrap everything in the framework of category theory. Aluffi's Algebra: Chapter Zero seemingly attempts a happy medium, and I am unhappy with it.

One fortunate aspect to Forester is that I'm not forced to choose one or the other. I can outline the "traditional" presentation of topics, and the "modern" presentation of topics, and allow the reader to pick which manner of presentation they wish to peruse.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cancellation law
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML group_1:6
Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Proposition 1.1.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let G be a Group, let a,b,c\in G. Then the following all hold:
If ac=bc, then a=b; and
If ca=cb, then a=b.

(1) Assume ac=bc, then multiply both sides on the right by c^{-1}, we see the left-hand side becomes (ac)c^{-1}=a(cc^{-1})=ae=a by assocativity and inverse, and the right-hand side becomes (bc)c^{-1}=b(cc^{-1})=be=b. Hence a=b.
(2) Assume ca=cb. Multiply both sides on the left by c^{-1} gives the result by similar reasoning as (1).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dihedral group
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.2
Hungerford Algebra Theorem 1.6.13

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a positive integer. We define the Dihedral group D_{n} to consist of the set \{x^{k}y^{j}\mid 0\leq k<n,0\leq j\leq 1\} where we also write x^{0}y^{0}=1, such that x^{n}=y^{2}=1 and also yx=x^{-1}y. It's not hard to see yx^{k}=x^{-k}y by applying that second relation k times.
(1) The dihedral group describes the symmetries of the regular n-gon in the plane, where x is rotation anticlockwise by 2\pi / n and y is reflection about a line through the origin.
(2) Some authors (like Dummit and Foote) call this group D_{2n} because it is of order 2n.
(3) D_{1} has x=1 and D_{0} is degenerate.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct sum of groups
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Exercise 5.1.17
MML group_7:def 9

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: General Linear Group of matrices
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.4

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This can be defined more generally replacing \mathbb {F} with a unital (possibly noncommutative) ring R, or even a ringoid (where we don't require additive inverses to exist).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Group
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML group_1:def
Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Group consists of a set G equipped with an Associative binary operator \star and an Identity element with respect to \star , usually denoted either e\in G or 1\in G, such that every element has a unique inverse, \forall a\in G\ldotp \exists a^{-1}\in A\ldotp a\star a^{-1}=a^{-1}\star a=e.
(1) When the binary operator for the group is commutative, we usually use + for the binary operator and 0 for the identity element.

(2) The "exact formalization" varies. For example, we could have equipped G with a binary operator \star , a unary operator (-)^{-1}\colon G\to G, and a constant element e\in G; this is what we will find useful in category theory later. But they are describing "the same thing". So don't worry about it if you're reading a textbook with a slightly different definition.

(3) The intuition is that G consists of bijections from a set to itself, and the binary operator is just the Composition of functions and the identity element is just the Identity function. These bijections are "symmetries" of the set.
(4) See also Forrester-Barker's Group objects and internal categories for a way to generalize the notion of groups to other settings.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Group Morphism
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML group_6:def 6bis
Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G and H be Groups. Let \varphi \colon G\to H be a function. We say \varphi is a Group Morphism (or just Morphism) if it preserves multiplication, i.e., for any g_{1},g_{2}\in G we have \varphi (g_{1}g_{2})=\varphi (g_{1})\varphi (g_{2}).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Group Isomorphism
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G and H be Groups. Let \varphi \colon G\to H be a Group Morphism. We say \varphi is a Group Isomorphism (or just Isomorphism) if it is bijective and has an inverse function which is a also a group morphism.
When G=H, we say \varphi is a Automorphism of G.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Isomorphic groups
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G and H be Groups. We typically say G and H are Isomorphic if there exists a Group Isomorphism between them. This is reflexive since the identity function is an automorphism.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Order of a group element
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML group_1:def 11
Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G be a Group. Let g\in G. We define Order of g is the integer \mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (g) equal to either the smallest positive integer n\in \mathbb {N} such that g^{n}=e or if no such positive integer exists, it is defined to be zero.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Some authors prefer \mathop {\mathrm {ord}}\nolimits (g) to be infinite if there is no smallest positive integer n such that g^{n}=e, but it can complicate some results.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product group
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let G and H be Groups. We define the Product Group G\times H whose underlying set is the Cartesian product of two sets of the sets underlying G and H, whose binary operator is given by (g_{1},h_{1})(g_{2},h_{2})=(g_{1}g_{2},h_{1}h_{2}) and the identity element is 1_{G\times H}=(1_{G},1_{H}).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quaternion Group
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.5
Hungerford Algebra Exercise 1.2.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We may define the Quaternion Group as consisting of the set Q_{8}=\{-1\}\cup \{i^{m}j^{n}k^{p}\mid 0\leq m,n,p\leq 3\} where we identify 1=i^{0}j^{0}k^{0} and it obeys the identities i^{2}=j^{2}=k^{2}=ijk=-1 and so we write -i=i^{3}, -j=j^{3}, and -k=k^{3}, and also (-1)^{2}=1. We have (-1)i=-i, (-1)j=-j, and (-1)k=-k. After a bit of work, we find ij=-ji=k jk=-kj=i ki=-ik=j

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Symmetric group of a set
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML cayley:def 2
Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set. We define the Symmetric Group of X to be the Group \mathop {\textrm {Sym}}\nolimits (X) consisting of all permutations on X, equipped with Composition of functions as its Binary operator.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Associative binary operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. We say \mu is Associative if \forall a,b,c\in X\ldotp \mu (a,\mu (b,c))=\mu (\mu (a,b),c)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Binary operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set. A Binary Operator (or, more archaically, Law of Composition) is a function \mu \colon X\times X\to X which is various denoted using infixed notation a\star b or a\cdot b or ab (or, if commutative, a+b) for any a,b\in X.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Commutative binary operator
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. We say \mu is Commutative if \forall a,b\in X\ldotp \mu (a,b)=\mu (b,a)

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Division algorithm
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any integers a,b\in \mathbb {Z}, there exists q,r\in \mathbb {Z} such that 0\leq r<|b| and a=qb+r.
We could take A=\{a-qb\mid q\in \mathbb {Z},a-qb\geq 0\}, then apply the Well-ordering principle to give us r as a minimal element of A.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Euler totient
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We have \varphi (n) be the number of positive integers less than n which are coprime to n, \varphi (n)=|\{k\in \mathbb {N}\mid k<n,\gcd (k,n)=1\}|. So \varphi (12)=|\{1,5,7,11\}|=4, but \varphi (11)=10.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Greatest common divisor
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If a,b\in \mathbb {Z} are nonzero integers, there exists a unique positive integer called the Greatest Common Divisor of a and b, usually denoted \gcd (a,b), such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: \gcd (a,b)\mathrel {\bigm |} a and \gcd (a,b)\mathrel {\bigm |} b (so \gcd (a,b) is a common divisor of a and b)
if e\mathrel {\bigm |} a and e\mathrel {\bigm |} b is another integer, then e\mathrel {\bigm |}\gcd (a,b) (so \gcd (a,b) is the greatest such divisor).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \gcd (a,b)=1 we say a and {b} are Coprime (or are Relatively Prime).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity element
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.1

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let \mu be a Binary operator on X. Let e\in X be an element. We say e is a Unit (or identity element) for \mu if \forall a\in X\ldotp \mu (a,e)=a\land \mu (e,a)=a.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Integers modulo n
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let n\in \mathbb {N} be a fixed positive integer. Let us define the Equivalence relation on the integers by a\sim b\iff n\mathrel {\bigm |}(b-a). This is reflexive (a\sim a since n\mathrel {\bigm |}(a-a)), symmetric (a\sim b\iff n\mathrel {\bigm |}(b-a)\iff n\mathrel {\bigm |}(a-b)\iff b\sim a) and transitive.
Then the quotient set \mathbb {Z} /\mathord {\sim } is often denoted \mathbb {Z} / n\mathbb {Z}. Moreover, there are well-defined operations [a]+[b]=[a+b] and [a]\cdot [b]=[a\cdot b].

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Quotient set
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.3

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Unique prime factorization
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any n\in \mathbb {N}, we may write it as a product n=p_{1}^{\alpha _{1}}(…)p_{k}^{\alpha _{k}} of distinct primes p_{i} and exponents \alpha _{i}\in \mathbb {N}. Here "uniqueness" means if we have another factorization n=q_{1}^{\beta _{1}}(…)q_{\ell }^{\beta _{\ell }}, then k=\ell and we have a bijection \sigma \colon \{1,…,k\}\to \{1,…,\ell \} such that p_{i}=q_{\sigma (i)} and \alpha _{i}=\beta _{\sigma (i)}. In other words, the two factorizations differ only in the ordering of factors.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Well-ordering principle
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 0.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Every nonempty subset A\subseteq \mathbb {N} has a minimal element:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \forall A\subseteq \mathbb {N}\ldotp A\neq \emptyset \implies \exists a\in A\ldotp \forall x\in A\ldotp a\leq x.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Dummit and Foote Abstract Algebra Section 1.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Field is traditionally defined as a set F with two binary operators, addition (denoted +) and multiplication (denoted \cdot ), satisfying the field axioms:

fr:ol.fr:li: Associativity of addition: for all x,y,z\in F, (x+y)+z=x+(y+z)
Commutativity of addition: for all x,y\in F, x+y=y+x
Additive identity: there exists a 0\in F such that for all x\in F we have 0+x=x and x+0=x
Additive inverses: for each x\in F there is a unique y\in F such that x+y=0 and y+x=0; in this case, we usually denote y as (-x)
Associativity of multiplication: for all x,y,z\in F, (x\cdot y)\cdot z=x\cdot (y\cdot z)
Commutativity of multiplication: for all x,y\in F, x\cdot y=y\cdot x
Multiplicative identity: there exists a 1\in F such that for all x\in F we have 1\cdot x=x and x\cdot 1=x
Multiplicative inverses: for each x\in F which is nonzero x\neq 0 there is a unique y\in F such that x\cdot y=1 and y\cdot x=1; usually we denote y as x^{-1}
Distributivity of multiplication over addition: for all x,y,z\in F, we have x\cdot (y+z)=(x\cdot y)+(x\cdot z) and (x+y)\cdot z=(x\cdot z)+(x\cdot y)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that some of these are redundant.
Also note: fields are usually written in blackboard bold, and the generic field is either \mathbb {F} or \Bbbk (since the German word for field is "Körper").
